qas.question: Three common types of sights are:
answers: Open, Aperture, Telescopic
Open, Telescopic, Parabolic
Aperture, Open, Telepathic
Telescopic, Button, Atabatic

qas.question: A telescopic sight may be used for:
answers: Placing your aim point on an animal that you have determined is legal and safe to harvest
Determining the number of antler tines on a downrange animal to assess whether it is legal to harvest
Identifying movement in the bush

qas.question: A legitimate way of rendering a firearm inoperable for storage is:
answers: Remove the bolt or bolt carrier
Hanging it on the wall more than 6 feet above the floor
Hiding it behind books on a shelf
Locking it in your car

qas.question: It is legal to store ammunition in the same locked container that the firearm is stored in:
answers: True
False

qas.question: In a remote wilderness area, a non-restricted firearm can be kept handy and unlocked:
answers: True
False

qas.question: The components of centrefire ammunition are:
answers: Case, Primer, Powder, Bullet
Base, Hull, Primer, Powder, Wad, Shot
Cartridge, Powder, Bullet
Round, Shot, Powder

qas.question: To PROVE a lever action rifle with a tubular magazine, you:
answers: Must operate the lever several times to make sure the contents of the magazine have been ejected
Must use an extraction tool to remove the contents of the tubular magazine
Have no need to remove ammunition from the magazine
Must remove the lever in addition to the magazine

qas.question: To PROVE a semi-automatic firearm, you:
answers: Must remove the magazine and then operate the cocking lever to eject the ammunition in the chamber
Must operate the cocking lever to eject the ammunition in the chamber, and then remove the magazine
Should put your finger in the action to see if the chamber is empty
Must remove the action to PROVE the firearm is safe

qas.question: The 3 parts of a firearm barrel are:
answers: Chamber, bore, muzzle
Firing pin, trigger, safety
Safety, chamber, muzzle
Muzzle, sights, stock

qas.question: The ACTS acronym stands for:
answers: Assume every firearm to be loaded; Control the muzzle; Trigger Finger - keep your finger off the trigger until ready to fire, See that it is safe, PROVE it is safe
Assess the situation, Control your breathing, Test the windage, Set your sights on the target
Aim the firearm, Control your breathing, Trigger - pull the trigger, Savour your harvest

qas.question: The PROVE acronym stands for:
answers: Point the firearm in the safest available direction, Remove all ammunition, Observe the chamber, Verify the feeding path, Examine the bore
Point the firearm in the safest available direction, Remove all ammunition, Observe the feed path, Verify the bore, Examine the chamber
Point the firearm in the safest available direction, Remove any obstactles from the barrel, Observe the chamber, Verify the feed path, Examine the magazine
Point the firearm at the sky, Remove all ammunition, Observe the chamber, Verify the feeding path, Examine the bore

qas.question: When removing ammunition as part of the PROVE procedure:
answers: Remove ammunition from the chamber first, then from the magazine (unless it is a semi-automatic action, in which case remove the magazine and then any ammunition in the chamber)
Remove any ammunition from the chamber first, then remove the magazine
Remove the magazine first, then any ammunition in the chamber
It doesn't matter whether you remove the ammunition from the chamber first, or remove the magazine first

qas.question: The 'A' in the ACTS acronym stands for:
answers: Assume the firearm to be loaded
Assume the firearm is loaded if nobody has told you it is already unloaded
Always check the firearm for damage
Always examine the chamber of the firearm

qas.question: The 'R' in the PROVE acronym stands for:
answers: Remove all ammunition
Remove the magazine
Remove any ammunition from the chamber of the gun
Remove the bore from the magazine
